newsitem.title: HONG KONG: HK stocks end flat, property stocks stay pressured.
newsitem.headline: HK stocks end flat, property stocks stay pressured.

text.p: Hong Kong stocks ended flat on Thursday, unable to retain the momentum of an early rally as property issues remained depressed and concerns about interest rates continued to dampen sentiment.
The Hang Seng Index rose 2.97 points, or 0.02 percent, to 13,288.40 after touching an early high of 13,405.54. Turnover was HK$10.01 billion compared with Wednesday's HK$11.89 billion.
"It is a quite disappointing performance," said Alex Wong, technical analyst at Dharmala Securities.
"Most of the property stocks are still under pressure. It is likely that the market will continue to consolidate."
Analysts said investors were still worried about the possibility of a U.S. interest rate rise at the Federal Reserve's policy setting meeting next week.
"Unless we see signs that the Fed is unlikely to raise rates in the short term, people will still be cautious and the market will continue to consolidate," said Wong.
Alex Tang, head of research at Yamaichi International, said the market seemed to have found support at 13,200 points and could try to test higher ground in the coming sessions.
"The short term trading range is still between 13,000 and 14,000 probably for the next three to four weeks," he added.
He said once the banks start to report earnings, the Hang Seng could try to test 14,000 points again. "But for the time being it looks like we are trying to test 13,500," Tang added.
In the banking sector, HSBC Holdings gained HK$2.00 to HK$177.50 and Bank of East Asia rose HK$0.50 to HK$35.80.
"Banking shares are likely to lead the rally the next time round. 1996 was a good year for banking," said Wong.
Bank of East Asia is due to release final results on Monday.
Property stocks continued to suffer from the Hong Kong Monetary Authority's recommendation this week that banks cap mortgage lending for luxury properties.
Henderson Land fell HK$0.25 to HK$72.25, Sun Hung Kai Properties shed HK$0.50 to HK$88.25 and Swire Pacific dropped HK$1.00 to HK$71.75.
China Light continued to rise following news CITIC would buy a stake in the utility. The stock gained HK$1.00 to HK$35.80.
GZI Transport Ltd, an infrastructure spinoff of Guangzhou Investment Co Ltd, made its trading debut on Thursday and closed at HK$4.875 compared with an issue price of HK$3.23.
January Hang Seng futures, which expired on Thursday, rose 71 points to 13,296.
